resources.string:
Warkworth castle was built in the mid-twelfth century originally as a timber castle. 

In the early 14th century the castle was upgraded by Edward II to protect against Scottish invasion. The castle successfully resisted Scottish invasion during the wars with Scotland. 

The Percy family took control of the caslte in 1345 and controlled it for the rest of its active life.

Dunstanburgh Castle was built in the early 14th-century by Thomas of Lancaster, who was the leader of a rebellion against Edward II. The rebellion was ill-fated, and Thomas was captured in battle and executed for his treason. 

The Duchy of Lancaster later took over the castle, with John of Gaunt expanding it greatly. The castle played a significant role in the War of the Roses and was captured and re-captured many times by Lancaster and Yorkish forces. 

The castle took such damage during this sustained war of the roses, and was never fully repaired.

Built during the age of Norman kings, this Caslte was sold to Queen Isabella who was the widow of Edward II. 

Isabella was of French nobility, and after the breakdown of her marriage with the King, she played a role in his removal from power when she allied with Roger Mortimer. 

Isabella and Mortimer ruled England for a short peroid after the removal of Edward II, but her son forced control of the country from here in 1330. Isabella was retired to Castle Rising to live out the rest of her days.

A Norman motte-and-bailey castle built in Norman times, this castle was expanded in the 12th century by Thomas Becket. 

The castle was besieged by King John during the rebellion of the Barons, with the Barons capturing the castle after a siege. 

By the 14th century the castle was used to hold royal prisoners and threats to the crown.

Originally a woodern fort constructed by William the Conqueror, this castle was upgraded to Stone in the 12th Century. 

The castle was used as a military fortress until the 17th century, when it was converted by the Greville family into a country home. 

The castle is still in fantastic condition today, and is one of the premier castles in England. Its journey from important military fortress to country home has been seemless.

This castle was the site of an important fortress in Northern England as far back at 420 AD. It later became an important Anglo-Saxon stronghold before being destroyed by the vikings in 993. 

The Normans built a new castle on this site, and it has been an important royal castle for much of its history. 

In the war of the roses, it became the first English caslte to be defeated by artillery in a long siege conducted by the Yorkist faction.

Alnwick Castle was built in early Norman times and was a very strong fortress in the north of England. 

Sitting close to the Scottish border, the castle was captured by King David of Scotland in 1136. It was unsuccesfully sieged by Scottish kings several other times in the century. 

In the 13th century the castle moved into the Percy family, an influentially and powerful historical family in the north of England. In 1572, Thomas Percy was executed for his continued loyalty to the Catholic Church. Another Percy took over the castle following this, but he was also killed for his role in the catholic gunpowder plot. After this the caslte left the family forever.

Dover Castle is one of the largest castles in England and due to its key location, it is probably the most militarily important castle in the country. 

Due to its critical location, a fortification likely existed on this site before the Roman conquest of Britain. It was significantly invested in by many kings, including Henry II who really started to turn the castle into what we can see today. 

During the English Civil war the castle was taken by the Parliamentarians without a single shot being fired due to its light defences. The castle was a useful and active military during the Napoleonic wars, and so was rebuilt during this peroid. It was also used during the Second World War.

Raby Castle was built by the influential Neville family in the 14th century, with Cecily Neville, the mother of Yorkist kings Richard and Edward, being born here. 

The crown took control of the castle when Charles Neville joined forces with Mary, Queen of Scots, to try and put her onto the English throne. 

The castle is now a lived-in country home that is in good condition.

Caernarfon Castle was a Motte-and-bailey castle built during Norman times. However, when Edward I established English rule over Wales, it was the site of one of the many castles he built in the country. 

The castle was the centre of English rule in Northern Wales. The castle was sacked during a Welsh revolt in the late 13th century, but Welsh rule over the castle only lasted until the next year when the English recaptured it. 

Due to their welsh roots, the Tudor dynasty in England saw a reduction in tension between England and Wales, making the castle less important as a military base. To this day, the Prince of Wales is traditionally annointed at this castle.
